en_second_half: of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pallid, jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ.

en_results_raw: of romantic playfulness that was in strange contrast with the grim courtyard below, where the marble statue of a Byzantine emperor watched over the silent, sleeping garden with a stern, unblinking gaze. Lord Henry's eyes, however, were not on the garden or the statue. They were fixed on the figure that had just entered the room. It was Basil Hallward, his friend and confidant, a man whose artistic sensibility was as finely tuned as his appreciation for the finer things in life. Basil's face was lit up with a glow that seemed to come from within, his dark hair slightly tousled, giving him an air of carefree elegance. He carried a portfolio under his arm, the leather worn and familiar, a testament to countless hours spent in the pursuit of beauty and truth through his brush. "Basil, my dear fellow, you are later than usual," Lord Henry greeted him, his voice smooth and laced with amusement. "I was beginning to think you were lost in the maze of your own thoughts." Basil smiled, a gesture that transformed his features into something almost angelic. "I was caught by a most extraordinary picture," he confessed, setting the portfolio down on the table beside the divan. "It's a portrait, of course, but there's something about it that is utterly captivating. The sitter is a young man, seemingly in the prime of life, with a face that is both haunting and beautiful. It's as though he embodies both the innocence of youth and the wisdom of ages past." Lord Henry leaned forward, his interest piqued. "And who is this mysterious Adonis?" he inquired, his tone playful yet genuinely curious. "His name is Dorian Gray," Basil replied, his eyes shining with enthusiasm. "I met him this morning at the park. He's new in town, or so he claims, and has already managed to intrigue everyone with his charm and his enigmatic persona. I've never seen anyone quite like him. There's something about him that is simply irresistible." Lord Henry's smile widened, a hint of something dangerous flickering in his gaze. "A new face in town, you say? Well, Basil, it seems we have a new subject for our artistic endeavors. Perhaps this Dorian Gray will provide the inspiration we've been lacking." Basil nodded, his excitement palpable. "Indeed, I believe he will. There's something about him that promises a masterpiece. And who knows, he might even become a friend." Lord Henry's laugh was light, yet it carried a note of cynicism. "Friends, Basil, are a luxury that one can do without. But a masterpiece? Now that is something worth pursuing." As they continued their conversation, the afternoon sun casting long shadows across the room, the two men were unaware that the arrival of Dorian Gray marked the beginning of a tale that would weave together art, beauty, and the darker aspects of human nature in a way they could never have anticipated.

Pero, al igual que la vida, eventualmente cae y se convierte en parte del pasado, dejando solo recuerdos. Sin embargo, es ese recuerdo, esa imagen etérea de la belleza que vivimos brevemente, lo que nos mantiene viva a través de los años, reflejando la esencia de lo que hemos experimentado. Así que, aunque esta margarita no es eterna, su significado es."

His heart pounded with a mixture of excitement and fear, unsure of what lay ahead. The silence around him seemed to amplify the noise of his own breathing, each inhale and exhale a reminder of his heightened state of being. He tried to focus, to will his mind to clarity, but it was as if a fog had descended, obscuring the path to understanding. His hands, which moments before had been clenched into tight fists, now trembled slightly, betraying his inner turmoil. He wondered if he was losing his mind, or if perhaps he was on the cusp of gaining something far greater. The world around him seemed to hold its breath, waiting for him to make the next move. Yet, for all his inner turmoil, he remained rooted to the spot, unable to take that decisive step forward into the unknown.

Cậu nhớ lại cuộc gặp gỡ đầu tiên với những người này, họ đã nói rằng họ sẵn sàng giúp cậu, nhưng đâu có nghĩa là đâu chỉ đến với hỗ trợ thôi. Theo những gì anh bạn nói, họ có thể đang dùng một loại thiết bị cấp cao để kiểm soát Basil, có thể là để tìm kiếm một vật dụng hoặc một diễn biến đáng chú ý. Cậu nhớ lại hình ảnh của những thiết bị đó, vô cùng đáng lo ngại. Basil càng phải chấp nhận sự thật đó, anh bạn của mình đã trở thành một nguồn thông tin quan trọng, mặc dù không hiểu tất cả về việc này. Anh bạn đang loay hoay, cố gắng tìm cách giúp Basil tránh khỏi tình huống nguy hiểm. "Chúng ta cần tìm một cách tránh xa khỏi họ", anh bạn nói, đưa Basil lên một con đường khác, cố gắng đi xa khỏi vùng xung quanh đang trở nên nguy hiểm hơn. Basil cảm thấy mình đã bị giam giữ trong một cơn tàn bạo của hoàn cảnh, mỗi chút đi xa càng làm cậu cảm thấy sợ hãi hơn. Anh bạn đang đưa cậu đi theo hunch và kinh nghiệm, nhưng chưa rõ liệu họ đủ khả năng tránh được tên lửa đang theo chặt giữa hai người. Cậu nhớ lại cuộc đời trước khi gặp anh này, cuộc sống đầy đam mê với rượu và kẻ thù bên ngoài, và hiện tại cậu đang trải qua một cuộc chiến tranh không giải pháp trong tâm trí. Theo đó, Basil cảm thấy mình đang trên con đường mà không thể trả lại, mỗi bước đang mang đến những giây phút mới và thách thức mới. Tuy nhiên, với sự giúp đỡ của anh bạn, cậu cũng cảm thấy một chút hòa bình, những nguyện vọng của mình vẫn còn sống sót. Hãy chờ đợi xem anh bạn có thể giúp Basil tránh được tình huống xấu xí, hoặc sẽ chỉ là một dấu chân trên con đường đầy rủi ro này.

A medida que el tiempo pasaba, sentía cómo sus pensamientos se mezclaban con pensamientos no identificados, formando un torrente de conocimiento ancestral que fluía por sus neuronas con una facilidad desconcertante. Su conciencia se expandía, alcanzando los confines de su mente, y quizás más allá, hacia un territorio que había estado oculto, esperando ser descubierto. Su visión se volvió más clara, casi telepática, como si pudiera ver las vibraciones de la realidad. Su sentido de presencia se intensificó, como si cada célula de su cuerpo estuviera clamorosa por expresar su existencia. Sin embargo, en medio de este caos estético y psíquico, sentía una calma profunda en su corazón, como si un maestro maestro le hubiera enseñado a encontrar la paz en el medio del caos. Este estado de ser, tan intensamente vivo y consciente, comenzó a transformar su percepción del mundo, llevándolo a cuestionar las limitaciones que antes consideró inquebrantables. Su mente se abrió como un libro antiguo, cuyas páginas estaban llenas de sabiduría perdida y conocimiento ancestral. Ahora, con esta nueva comprensión, se preguntaba qué le depararía su camino adelante.

es_results_raw: una diferencia sustancial. El matrimonio es un compromiso, pero el prometimiento es algo más flexible y puede no implicar un compromiso legal. En este mundo, donde las alianzas pueden ser tan fluidas como el agua, un prometimiento puede significar cualquier cosa, desde una simple declaración de intención hasta un firme compromiso sin formalidad legal. Lord Henry, con su característico sarcasmo, sugiere que, en este contexto, el prometimiento es menos confinador y más adecuado para aquellos que prefieren la libertad y la incertidumbre sobre los detalles más concretos de una relación. Su comentario subraya la idea de que, en ciertas sociedades, como la de la que habitan estos personajes, las alianzas y promesas son más ligadas a la personalidad y a los deseos individuales de los involucrados que a una estructura formal y legal. Esto puede sugerir también una crítica a las expectativas sociales y a las normas tradicionales de matrimonio, presentando el prometimiento como una alternativa más flexible y personalizada a la formalidad del matrimonio. Lord Henry, con su perspicacia y su visión crítica, utiliza este comentario para explorar las complejidades de las relaciones humanas y las expectativas sociales, sugiriendo que, en ciertas circunstancias, la libertad y la flexibilidad pueden ser valoradas más que la formalidad y la estabilidad tradicional. Su frase resuena con una profunda reflexión sobre el significado real de los compromisos personales en una sociedad que está en constante evolución, donde las normas y valores tradicionales pueden ser cuestionados y redefinidos.

en_first_half: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves,
en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”
en_results: and yet we are so deeply moved that our sense of identity becomes confused. We suffer, sometimes we are even shattered, but it is the suffering of the soul, the tragedy of the spirit, which keeps us awake at night and makes us think of the problems that lie beyond the sphere of art. It is this intersection of life's raw pain with the refined expression of art that creates a profound emotional experience. We are confronted with our own mortality, our own insignificance, and yet, paradoxically, we find a strange comfort in the fact that our pain has been given form, that it has been transmuted into something beautiful and enduring. This is why certain tragedies, those that are imbued with a sense of artistry, affect us so deeply. They remind us of our own fragility

They remind us of our own fragility and the fleeting nature of our existence, but they also elevate our suffering, making it something noble and worthy of contemplation. In the end, we are left with a bittersweet appreciation for the pain that has been artistically rendered, a recognition that in the midst of chaos and despair, there can be moments of transcendent beauty.

es_first_half: —Es un caso interesante —dijo lord Henry, que encontraba un placer sutil enjugar con el egoísmo inconsciente de su joven amigo—; un caso sumamente interesante. Creo que la verdadera explicación es ésta: sucede con frecuencia que las tragedias reales de la vida ocurren de una manera tan poco artística que nos hieren por lo crudo de su violencia, por su absoluta incoherencia, su absurda ausencia de significado, su completa falta de estilo. Nos afectan como lo hace la vulgaridad. Sólo nos producen una impresión de fuerza bruta, y nos rebelamos contra eso. A veces, sin embargo, cruza nuestras vidas una tragedia que posee elementos de belleza artística. Si esos elementos de belleza son reales, todo el conjunto apela a nuestro sentido del efecto dramático. De repente descubrimos que ya no somos los actores, sino los espectadores de la obra. O que
es_second_half: somos más bien las dos cosas. Nos observamos, y el mero asombro del espectáculo nos seduce. En el caso presente, ¿qué es lo que ha sucedido en realidad? Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustaría haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sí algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo después de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mí. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. ¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! ¡Qué cosa más espantosa! ¡Y qué total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.

en_second_half: shown his secret? Were people to gape at the mystery of his life? That was impossible. Something—he did not know what—had to be done at once.

en_results_raw: to know the horrors that he had acted? The idea of his soul becoming public property filled him with a dread that he hardly dared to analyze. He looked at Lord Henry, whose cynical smile seemed to mock his sudden panic, and then at Basil, whose romantic features were distorted with horror and surprise. "It is too horrible, too dreadful!" he cried, "I cannot bear the thought of my soul being exposed like that. It remains hidden within me, and I feel that it is safer there. No one can judge it as it really is. They can only judge me as I appear to them, and that is my disguise. I am not what I have been, and what I have been is not what I shall be." His voice shook, and he passed his hand across his forehead, as though to wipe away the mist of a feverish delirium. "Yes, it must never be revealed," he continued, more calmly, though his eyes were still bright with a wild anxiety. "I cannot bear my own secrets, and I am afraid of what others would say. It would profane my soul, too sacred for this world, and life would become unbearable. I must protect it at any cost, and the price is not too high to pay." He paused, and for a moment he seemed lost in thought. "Besides," he added, with a curious smile, "even if I wished to do so, how could I exhibit it? It is invisible, as you very well know."

The room seemed to close in on him, the air heavy with the scent of jasmine from the garden outside, a stark contrast to the turmoil within. He pulled the curtains aside, letting the pale light of dawn fill the space, chasing away the shadows that had gathered in the corners. The painting on the wall, a portrait of his own image, seemed to watch him with an inscrutable gaze, as if it held the secret to his soul. He turned away, unable to meet its unblinking stare, and sank down onto the chaise longue, his hands trembling slightly as he ran them through his hair. The night's excesses weighed heavily on him, a burden he feared he would never be able to shed. He knew he had crossed a line from which there was no return, and the thought filled him with a mixture of dread and exhilaration.

es_results_raw: Cuando se perdió el ruido de sus pisadas, Dorian cerró la puerta y se guardó la llave en el bolsillo. Ahora, sentado en el sofá de madera antigua, observó la habitación vacía, susurra sus propias pensamientos mientras el crepúsculo se apoderaba del salón. La luz tenue se filtraba a través de las cortinas, creando sombras que bailaban sobre el suelo. Dorian recordaba cada momento compartido con ella, cada risa, cada silencio comprensivo. La nostalgia se abalanzó sobre él como una oleada de olas, cada uno cargado de recuerdos que ahora parecían un manto de seda desgastado por el tiempo. ¿Qué decision tomaría ahora? ¿Reanudar sus esfuerzos por encontrarla o aceptar que la aventura se había desvanecido como el último rayo antes del anochecer? Mientras la cama se llenaba con sombras, Dorian se sentó más profundo, enfrentándose a la realidad de que, quizás, el camino más difícil sería superar el silencio que ahora reinaría en su corazón.

vi_results_raw: of life that prioritizes logic and reason over personal fulfillment and emotional experience. This new ideology, much like a modern-day Prometheus, will bring enlightenment, offering solutions that transcend the rigid dogmas of past moral codes, which have long shackled the human spirit. It will champion a future where intellectual prowess is revered, yet it will never condone the sacrifice of ethical principles in the pursuit of knowledge. This new doctrine will advocate for a harmonious coexistence between the rational and the emotional, ensuring that progress does not come at the expense of our humanity. It will propose a society where innovation is not a race against the clock, but a measured, thoughtful evolution that considers the well-being of all its members. In this envisioned future, technology and artificial intelligence will be seen not as replacements for human intelligence, but as extensions of it, amplifying our capabilities without diminishing our essence. Education and research will be at the forefront, fostering a generation that is not only knowledgeable but also empathetic, capable of understanding the complex interplay between science and society. The arts and humanities will not be sidelined but integrated into the fabric of education, ensuring a balanced development of the human mind. This new ideology will challenge us to redefine success, shifting the focus from mere material wealth to a more holistic measure of well-being that includes personal fulfillment, community connection, and environmental stewardship. It will encourage a lifestyle that is sustainable and equitable, where the prosperity of one does not come at the expense of another. In this new era, governance will be transparent and participatory, with technology serving as a tool to enhance democracy rather than undermine it. The legal system will evolve to reflect a more nuanced understanding of justice, incorporating principles of restorative rather than retributive justice. This new Chủ nghĩa khoái lạc will not be a monolith but a dynamic framework adaptable to the diverse needs and aspirations of different cultures and communities. It will recognize that while there is a universal quest for meaning and happiness, the paths to these goals are as varied as the people who walk them. In essence, this new ideology will be a beacon of hope, guiding humanity towards a future where the potential for greatness is unlocked not by the suppression of our diverse selves, but by the celebration and integration of our multifaceted existence.

en_results_raw: woke up. The sunlight streamed into the room, wakening him with its touch. He sat up in bed, rubbing his eyes and yawning. The servant waited patiently, giving him a moment to gather his thoughts. Dorian stretched his limbs, feeling the day ahead of him with a mix of anticipation and dread. He swung his legs over the side of the bed, his feet touching the cool, polished floor. He ran a hand through his hair, attempting to smooth out the disarray from sleep. "Bring the chocolate over here, will you?" Dorian asked, his voice still rough with sleep. The servant nodded and placed the tray on the bedside table. Dorian picked up the cup, the steam from the hot liquid curling up towards his face. He inhaled deeply, the rich scent of chocolate filling his nostrils and bringing a sense of comfort. He took a sip, letting the warmth of the drink spread through his mouth and down his throat. The bitterness of the chocolate was just right, a perfect start to the day. He looked out of the window, seeing the city waking up around him. The noise of traffic and the bustle of people began to filter through the open shutters. Dorian felt a pang of guilt for having slept in so late, knowing that his friends were probably already at the studio, waiting for him. He set the cup down and swung his legs off the bed, standing up with a determined look on his face. "I must dress and join them," he murmured to himself, the reality of his commitments finally sinking in. He began to move around the room, selecting his clothes with care, each piece chosen to reflect his current mood and the day's activities. As he dressed, he thought about the portrait that awaited him, the secret it held, and the consequences that might follow if anyone discovered the truth behind his youthful appearance.

es_results_raw: Con dificultad, Campbell se apoyó contra la pared, intentando encontrar algo que pudiera usar para calmar su mareo. La oscuridad del salón parecía intensificarse con cada respiración, y la sensación de incertidumbre lo envolvía como una nube. Su mente vacilaba entre buscar ayuda o quedarse allí, esperando que el malestar pasara. Decidió que no podía quedarse inmóvil, y comenzó a caminar de un lado a otro, intentando encontrar algo que pudiera servir como remedio casero. Su mirada se desorientó mientras exploraba la habitación, buscando cualquier signo de que alguien hubiera dejado algo de ayuda. La soledad era abrumadora, y cada sombra parecía moverse con propósito, aumentando su nerviosismo. Finalmente, su ojo cayó sobre una botella de agua que había sido olvidada bajo una alfombra. Con una mezcla de desesperación y esperanza, Campbell se agachó y tomó la botella, intentando encontrar algo que la pudiera usar para calmar su fiebre. La idea de recoger fuego o algún otro elemento químico no se le ocurreció, pero la presencia de agua le ofrecía un alivio temporal. It is you who are our greatest friends, because you are the only ones who tell us the truth. The others lie." She swept the room with a graceful gesture. "Who is your greatest friend, Lord Henry?" she asked. "You," he answered, with grave surprise. "And you, Dorian?" she inquired, turning to him with a playful archness of the eyebrow. "I hope Mr. Basil Hallward," he replied, with a polite grave smile. "The picture-painter?" she exclaimed in pretended astonishment. "Yes," said Dorian, "the picture-painter." She laughed. "And what is it that you admire most in him?" she inquired. "His hands," he answered in a grave tone. "They are extraordinary hands," she cried, holding up her own with a mock display of admiration. "I wish I had such hands." "You have," murmured Lord Henry, watching her with his half-closed eyes. "Well, I wish I had them," she insisted. "You would cut them off," whispered Dorian with a touch of malice. "They would be a nuisance to me," she cried. "Much more trouble than they are worth. Besides, I hate working with them. I like to be admired for my beauty, not for my skill." She looked at them both with a demure air. "Besides, gentlemen, skill takes time, and time is very soon gone. Beauty, on the contrary, remains for ever." Lord Henry drew a long, voluptuous sigh. "How true, my dear Lady Henry!" he murmured. "Yes," she answered, touching the pink petals with her fingers, "and it is the only thing in life that is really worth working for." "I am afraid you are right," murmured Dorian, "but I never work at all." "Never work?" echoed Lady Henry, opening wide her dark eyes in mock amazement. "Never! Well, I must say I am glad to hear it. It is the only piece of news that I have heard today that has surprised me." She laughed again, a pleasant, musical laugh that seemed to charm the air. "Well, gentlemen, what is your next move? Will you join me in a game of whist, or play at romps over the lawn? Romps are so much more satisfactory. Don't you think so, Mr. Dorian?" "I would rather be running over the grass with you, Lady Henry, than playing whist with anybody," he answered, with a graceful bow. "Ah, you men are all the same," she cried, "far too fond of idling away your time. However, I am always delighted to have you here. You must come often. I get dreadfully bored if I don't see any of you for a week. Life is so much more interesting when you are present." Lord Henry looked at her with a curious expression. "You are a very charming woman, Lady Henry," he murmured, "and you have the additional charm of being very dangerous." "Dangerous?" she echoed, moving her chair a little nearer to him. "How dangerous?" "Because," he whispered, with a smile, "you have a perfect instinct for secret things." She laughed again. "I hope you don't consider secret things as sinful things, Lord Henry. There is no sin in seeing life as it is." "There is no sin in seeing life as it is," he repeated, "but there is a sin in not wanting to see it as it is." She bit her lip. "Ah, don't, Lord Henry, don't!" she exclaimed. "You take away all my pleasure in life." "I am sorry," he answered, with an air of mock regret. "I didn't intend to offend you, Lady Henry." "You never intend to offend," she retorted, "and yet you always do." "I assure you it is merely an accident," he replied. "Well, don't commit it again," she cried, rising to her feet. "Come, Mr. Dorian, let us go out on the lawn. The day is perfect, and we have only this one. Life is a brief interlude before the common end." Dorian Gray watched them both as they moved towards the door. There was something in the graceful, mocking insolence of Lady Henry's manner that fascinated him. La pasión, entonces, era su escudo y su espada, su motor y su combustible, llevándolo hacia un futuro incierto pero lleno de posibilidades, donde la verdad de su existencia se revelaría no en las apariencias, sino en las acciones consistentes con su verdadero carácter.

Su risa era extraña, casi sin voz, y sentía una presencia oscura que envolvía el salón. "¿Quién sos?" preguntó Dorian, intentando mantener la calma, aunque su corazón latía con fuerza en su pecho. "Estás perdido, ¿no?" continuó ella, su voz tan baja que era difícil entender las palabras. "No, no estoy perdido", contestó Dorian, aunque sintió una mezcla de miedo y confusión. "Soy alguien que necesita hablar contigo", agregó, intentando mantener la postura de alguien seguro y decidido. La mujer levantó lentamente los ojos, y su mirada se enraizó en él, como si pudiera penetrar su alma. "Entonces, comencemos", dijo, finalmente rompiendo el silencio que reinaía en la habitación. Dorian respiró profundamente, preparándose para lo que podría ser una conversación desafiante y reveladora. "¿Cómo te conocí?" fue su primer pregunta, tratando de establecer un marco de normalidad en la situación extraña que se había desencadenado. La mujer sonrió, una sonrisa que no consiguió transmitir alegría, y respondió con una voz que parecía provenir de los más profundos reinos del silencio. "Desde el principio, Dorian. Desde que tu alma se desplazó hacia mí, como un eco perdido de un sueño olvidado." Su frase fue tan inesperada que Dorian se quedó estancado, preguntándose si había caído en una locura o si, de hecho, algo fuera de lo común estaba sucediendo. "¿Cómo sabes todo eso?" preguntó finalmente, su voz llena de incredulidad. La mujer se levantó, acercándose a él hasta casi tocarse frente a frente. "Porque, Dorian, soy la verdad que has estado buscando. Pero, ¿estás listo para descubrirla?" Su pregunta resonó en el silencio, dejando a Dorian en una mezcla de asombro y temor ante lo que podría revelar su verdadera identidad y el misterioso destino que se avecinaba.

Dorian's keen eyes scanned the dense undergrowth, his senses heightened by the excitement. He could hear the rustle of leaves and the soft patter of small animals scurrying away from the disturbance. es_first_half: —Mi querido muchacho —dijo lord Henry sonriendo—, cualquiera puede ser bueno en el campo, donde no existen tentaciones. Ése es el motivo de que las personas que no habitan en ciudades vivan todavía en estado de barbarie.
es_second_half: La civilización no es algo que se consiga fácilmente. Sólo hay dos maneras. O se es culto o se está corrompido. La gente del campo carece de ocasiones para ambas cosas, de manera que sólo conocen el estancamiento.
es_results: En la sociedad moderna, las tentaciones son omnipresentes, incluso en las ciudades que parecen ser el epitome de la cultura y la civilización. Sin embargo, el señor Henry argumenta que la verdadera bondad reside en
es_results_raw: En la sociedad moderna, las tentaciones son omnipresentes, incluso en las ciudades que parecen ser el epitome de la cultura y la civilización. Sin embargo, el señor Henry argumenta que la verdadera bondad reside en resistir a estas tentaciones, en un entorno donde las oportunidades para ceder son constantes. Las personas que viven en el campo, a menudo desprovistas de estas "tentaciones", pueden desarrollar una integridad moral más inquebrantable, simplemente porque no están constantemente bombardeadas por las influencias negativas que caracterizan a las ciudades. La vida rural, con sus ritmos más lento y sus tradiciones más profundas, puede cultivar valores más auténticos y sencillos. Por lo tanto, aunque las ciudades pueden parecer el hogar de la "civilización", no necesariamente significan que su habitante estén en un estado superior moralmente. En cambio, podría argumentarse que la verdadera bondad y santidad están más cerca de aquellos que viven en un entorno más simple y menos corrupto, donde las decisiones éticas son menos complicadas por las presiones sociales y económicas omnipresentes en las ciudades.

es_results_raw: continuación: continuation de la historia de Oscar Wilde, donde Dorian Gray es el personaje principal. Oscar Wilde, el autor, explora temas como la moralidad, el hedonismo y el impacto de la belleza externa sobre la conciencia interior a través de la trama. Dorian Gray es un joven apasionado por la belleza y el placer, pero sus acciones se desvían de su naturaleza intrínseca cuando comete un asesinato y su cara en el cuadro mágico no refleja el peso de sus crímenes. Su amigo, Lord Henry Wotton, influye en él con sus ideales hedonistas, lo que lleva a Dorian a un viaje de descenso moral. A medida que el tiempo pasa, Dorian experimenta cambios drásticos tanto en su apariencia como en su conducta, mientras intenta esconder sus actos oscuros. La narrativa se centra en la lucha interna de Dorian, su deseo de salvación y el impacto de sus decisiones en sus relaciones personales, especialmente con la amante de su juventud, Sybil Vane, y su hermano, Basil Hallward, el artista que pintó su retrato mágico. Oscar Wilde emplea un lenguaje elaborado y una estructura narrativa compleja para explorar estos temas, utilizando dialogos que reflejan profundamente las ideas filosóficas de su época. La continuidad de la historia podría explorar cómo Dorian lucha con el peso de sus acciones, su relación con Lord Henry, y cómo su vida se desmorona ante sus propios deseos y las influencias externas. La novela finaliza con un giro trágico que refleja los consecuencias de las decisiones de Dorian y su búsqueda de redención, dejando al lector con una reflexión profunda sobre la naturaleza humana y la búsqueda de la verdadera belleza.

I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London
en_second_half: is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.”

The street preacher, though vulgar, held a certain sway over his audience, didn't he? His question, though simple, cut through the noise of the city and demanded an answer. The scene lingered in my mind, prompting me to reflect on the emptiness that can sometimes pervade our lives, despite our wealth and status. Cuando iba por el Parque este último domingo, me encontré, cerca de Marble Arch, un grupito de gente mal vestida escuchando a un vulgar predicador callejero. Cuando pasaba por delante, oí cómo aquel hombre le gritaba esa pregunta a su público. Todo ello me pareció bastante dramático. En Londres abundan los
es_second_half: efectos curiosos como ése. Un domingo lluvioso, un vulgar cristiano con un impermeable, un círculo de blancos rostros enfermizos bajo un techo desigual de paraguas goteantes, y una frase maravillosa lanzada al aire por unos labios histéricos y una voz chillona..., estuvo bastante bien, a su manera: toda una sugerencia. Se me ocurrió decirle al profeta que el Arte sí tiene un alma, pero no el ser humano. Mucho me temo, de todos modos, que no me hubiera entendido.

tr_results_raw: bir gün günü, London'un karnı gibi derin ve somut bir atmosfer ile dolu. Mermer Kemer'in kıyı yüzüne doğru doğru ilerlediğimde, parkın üstünde yürüyüşüyle kendimi gösteren insanlar, manzaraya paralel bir çizgi çiziyorlardı. Bir kısmı kahve içiyorlardı, bir kısmı kitap okuyorlardı, bazıları kendilerini film çekimi yapmaya çalışıyorlardı. Lord Henry'nin kolları, bu dinleyici bir dalganın ardına çekişti. “Bilgi, henüz biraz daha iyi bir hazine olduğunu düşünüyorum,” dedi Lord Henry, kafes içine daldı. “Bu dünyada her şey, belki de belirsizlikle dolu olabilir, ancak bilgi, hiçbir zaman belirsiz olmayacaktır. On, gerçekliğin derinliklerine ulaşmanın anahtarı olabilir.” Mermer Kemer'in adamı, Lord Henry'nin katılımıyla konuştuğu anı hafızasında saklandı. “Bu sahneler, hayatımın en güzel kısmını oluşturuyor,” diyor Mermer Kemer. “Bir kıyamete atıfta bulunmak, gerçek anlamıyla yaşama fırsatıdır.” Lord Henry, yüzünü merdivenlerden çıkararak, “Hayatın her anı, bir kitap gibi, kısa ve uzun süreli bir hikaye olabilir. Ve her hikaye, bir başka hikayenin ardına bir parça olabilir.” Mermer Kemer'in kıyısı, Lord Henry'nin düşünceleriyle dolu hale geldi. London'un derinliklerine inilerek, her sahnede bir anlam arayan bir yolculuğa devam etti.
